data.title: Crypto at 50% discount to trend offers multi-year opportunity, Pantera’s Morehead says
data.description:
Dan Morehead, founder and managing partner of Pantera Capital, believes now is an excellent time to invest in cryptocurrency for those with a multi-year investment horizon.

In an interview with CNBC, Morehead pointed out that crypto is currently trading at a 50% discount to its long-term trend, placing it at its seventh percentile value against an eight-year trend average—meaning 93% of the time historically, crypto has been priced higher than it is today.

Morehead highlighted what he sees as a compelling relative value opportunity between crypto and artificial intelligence stocks. “We track an index of the top 10 AI companies, and they’re trading about 20% over their long-term trend, and crypto’s trading at a 50% discount to its long-term trend,” he explained. “So as a kind of relative value investor, I think crypto is very cheap relative to AI at this point.”

The former CFO and head of macro trading at Tiger Management noted that Bitcoin follows a predictable four-year cycle tied to its halving events, when the number of new bitcoins issued gets cut in half. He pointed to Pantera’s accurate forecast from several years ago that predicted Bitcoin would hit $117,482 on a specific date in August 2025. “It did that day,” Morehead confirmed, though he acknowledged the subsequent pullback was also expected.

Regarding how far Bitcoin could fall, Morehead observed that the severity of downturns has been decreasing with each cycle. “The first cycle… it was 87%, then it was 80%, then 74% loss. Now it’s at 50,” he said, suggesting the current correction’s floor is likely around $50,000 to $60,000. “But again, if you have a multiyear time frame, these are great prices.”

Morehead also expressed caution about traditional markets, noting that the Federal Reserve “has flooded so much liquidity in the markets” and that “everything is pretty rich.” He specifically mentioned that bonds are trading 50 basis points below their fifty-year average on real rates, while the Nasdaq appears “fully valued” to him.

Beyond Bitcoin, Morehead emphasized the importance of portfolio diversification within crypto, noting that Pantera maintains a large position in Solana despite its recent decline. He also highlighted real-world blockchain applications, citing the example of $20 billion in mortgages already placed on blockchain technology, which is reducing spreads between borrowers and lenders by over 100 basis points.

data.title: Chicago PMI
data.description: Chicago PMI: 57.7 in February vs. 52.5 consensus and 54.0 in January, according to data released by the Institute for Supply Management on Friday.

data.title: Barclays mulls creation of blockchain platform to handle payments, other processes - report
data.description:
Barclays (BCS) (BCLYF) is reportedly considering the creation of a blockchain platform to handle payments and other processes.

The bank's push into blockchain technology could include payments applications like stablecoins and tokenized deposits, people familiar with the matter told Bloomberg News.

The U.K.-based lender has approached some potential technology suppliers, and aims to select providers as soon as April, according to the people, who asked not to be named as the deliberations are private.

The report comes as global banking giants are said to be exploring the use of digital asset technology for various banking services.

BCS shares extended losses from the prior session on Friday before the market open to trade 1.82% lower at $24.83.

Barclays was said to be among the Wall Street lenders exposed to the failed UK mortgage finance firm, Market Financial Solutions.

data.title: AES Corp. gains on report GIP, EQT close to acquisition
data.description:
AES Corp. (AES) rose 5% on a report that BlackRock Inc.’s  (BLK) Global Infrastructure Partners LP and EQT AB are in talks to purchase the power company.

A deal could be announced as soon as next week, according to a Bloomberg report  on Friday, which cited people familiar with the matter. A final agreement hasn't been reached, and the timing could still change. 

AES (AES) has been exploring options, including a sale after receiving takeover interest from infrastructure investors including GIP, Bloomberg reported earlier.

On  Friday, AES (AES)  rescheduled its Q4 results from today until Tuesday.

Virginia-based AES (AES) owns a fleet of renewable generation, including wind and solar, as well as natural gas and coal assets and a utility in Indiana and Ohio.

data.title: Stock market slides after hot wholesale inflation report
data.description:
Wall Street opened in the red, lower on Friday, as the January wholesale inflation report came in hotter than expected. 

The S&P 500 (SP500) -0.9%, the Dow (DJI) -0.9%, and the Nasdaq Composite (COMP:IND) -1.3%.

The January U.S. Producer Price Index came in at +0.5% M/M vs. +0.3% consensus and +0.5% prior and +2.9% Y/Y vs. +2.6% consensus and +3.0% prior.

The Core PPI (excluding food and energy) came in at +0.8% M/M vs. +0.3% consensus and +0.7% prior, and +3.6% Y/Y vs. +3.0% consensus and +3.3% prior.

Also on the calendar, the Chicago PMI is due during market hours and is forecasted to retreat to 52.5 from a remarkably strong 54.0 in January, following years of contraction.

U.S. Treasury yields edged lower as traders awaited the inflation data. The 10-year Treasury yield (US10Y) fell to 3.99%, while the 2-year Treasury yield (US2Y) slipped to 3.41%. The 30-year Treasury yield (US30Y) moved to 4.65%.

data.title: Xponential Fitness slips further into the red, agrees to settle with FTC for $17M
data.description:
Xponential Fitness (XPOF) was limping into Friday’s open with shares down more than 20% on the heels of a sizable miss in its fourth quarter results that include a much larger-than-expected loss and expectations for revenue to fall by 16% in FY26.

Moreover, the company agreed to pay $17M over the next 12 months to settle allegations with the Federal Trade Commission over allegations that Xponential (XPOF) misled franchisees over financial projections and the financial health of certain fitness studios.

While the company has not admitted to any liability, it has agreed to pay another $22.75M to settle claims with 500 current and former franchisees, to be paid over a 35-month period.

For the reported quarter, Xponential Fitness (XPOF) generated $83M in sales, down 0.33% from a year ago and $9.6M less than expected.

The company also slipped further into the red with an adjusted loss of $0.91 per share from a loss of $0.19 in the same quarter last year and $0.88 worse than anticipated. Stripping out certain items, a key operating income metric was also down from a year ago, with adjusted EBITDA at $22.9M from $30.8M last year.

For FY26, the company sees revenue to be between $260M and $270M, down 16% from FY25 and less than the consensus estimate of $299.4M. 

Adjusted EBITDA is expected to be down 6% to be between $100M and $110M.

“As we enter 2026, we are focused on driving organic growth and elevating the member experience. We are making intentional investments to drive member acquisition and retention, even if this results in more modest near-term Adjusted EBITDA," said Xponential Fitness CEO Mike Nuzzo.

data.title: PAR Technology anticipates mid-teens ARR growth and $15M OpEx savings through AI-driven automation in 2026
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: PAR Technology Corporation (PAR) Q4 2025

Management View

  • CEO Savneet Singh reaffirmed PAR's strategy as "becoming an AI-driven hospitality platform company," highlighting its two verticals—restaurants and retail—as "individually mid-teens ARR growers with significant white space." Singh emphasized aggressive investment into the AI platform, stating, "We have never felt more confident about our positioning and the opportunity set in front of us."
  • Singh reported Q4 revenue of $120.1 million, up 14% year-over-year, driven by strength in subscription services and hardware. He also noted, "On a non-GAAP basis, we generated $2.6 million of net income, marking our third consecutive quarter of non-GAAP profitability."
  • PAR secured a decade-long partnership with Papa Johns for 3,200 sites, with Singh indicating further expansion opportunities: "We anticipate increasing our partnership with Papa Johns in the future with both expansion to select international markets and continued expansion within our platform."
  • Singh announced new AI products, including Coach AI and PAR Drive AI, stating, "Our first AI product, Coach AI is now being utilized by nearly 1,000 stores with roughly 1,000 active users," and described significant enhancements with "prescriptive operator recommendations."
  • CFO Bryan Menar stated, "We closed out 2025 with our most successful quarter in recent history. From our strong bookings, incremental ARR of $17 million and down through to our $7 million adjusted EBITDA."
  • Menar reported, "Subscription Services continue to fuel our organic growth and represented 63% of total Q4 revenue. The growth from higher-margin revenue streams resulted in a consolidated non-GAAP gross margin of $61 million, an increase of $8 million or 16%, compared to Q4 prior year."

Outlook

  • Singh indicated, "We expect ARR to continue to grow in the mid-teens. And similar to last year, the net growth will be more muted in the first half of the year versus the second half."
  • He outlined plans to "eliminate roughly $15 million annualized OpEx through AI-driven automation and the natural synergies of operating at our scale by the end of Q1."
  • Singh said, "You should expect for us to deploy parts of our operational expense savings into AI platform production."

Financial Results

  • PAR reported total revenues of $120 million for Q4 2025, an increase of 14% compared to the same period in 2024, with subscription service revenue growth of 18%.
  • Net loss from continuing operations for Q4 was $21 million, or $0.51 loss per share. Non-GAAP net income for Q4 was $2.6 million, or $0.06 earnings per share. Adjusted EBITDA was $7 million, up $1.2 million sequentially and $1.3 million year-over-year.
  • ARR exiting the quarter was $315 million, an increase of 16% from last year's Q4.
  • Hardware revenue was $28 million, up 7%, while gross margin was $49 million, up 10%. Non-GAAP subscription service margin for Q4 was 65.8%, and excluding a fixed product contract, reached 71%.
  • Operating expenses excluding non-GAAP adjustments were $54 million, up 15% year-over-year, driven mainly by increased R&D investment.
  • As of year-end, cash and cash equivalents stood at $80 million.

Q&A

  • George Sutton, Craig-Hallum: Asked about Singh's confidence and the acceleration of enterprise AI deals. Singh responded, "My excitement is really in the AI investments and the AI excitement from our customers... AI is an operational imperative for them."
  • Mayank Tandon, Needham: Asked about restaurant market conditions and ARR guidance. Singh responded, "This is a complicated environment for restaurants... we think it's a perfect environment to sell, and we think it's even a more perfect environment to use AI."
  • Stephen Sheldon, William Blair: Queried about customer willingness to make software changes and R&D investments. Singh said, "It's a great environment right now to be in our category... the pipeline created from the large enterprise, but the medium enterprise... are moving as well."
  • Jeremy Sahler, Jefferies: Asked about ARPU at Papa Johns and ARR growth mix. Singh said, "It's market pricing for us... As far as future opportunities, we sort of see 2 direct potential opportunities... upselling the brand on other products... and international expansion."
  • Andrew Harte, BTIG: Inquired about share buyback and growth visibility. Singh said, "We want to have the optionality to return capital to our investors in every which way possible... the majority of our plan for the year is pretty much there."
  • Charles Nabhan, Stephens: Asked about supply chain impacts. Singh stated, "We're not seeing any impact yet on the revenue side... But we are seeing on the cost side, where our margins were mid-20s, I think we expect margins will be 20%, 21%."
  • Maxwell Michaelis, Lake Street: Asked about investment in the Bridg acquisition and M&A priorities. Singh replied, "Of course, we're going to invest in it, but... it is not going to be a cash burn within Bridg... M&A is lower on the priority list given where our stock price is."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts expressed cautious optimism, focusing on AI adoption, growth visibility, and profitability, but pressed for clarity around guidance and supply chain impacts.
  • Management maintained a confident tone in prepared remarks and Q&A, repeatedly emphasizing their AI strategy and operational resilience. Singh stated, "We have never felt more confident about our positioning and the opportunity set in front of us."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, the tone remained optimistic, but current commentary placed increased emphasis on AI-driven transformation and upcoming cost efficiencies.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance language shifted to emphasize mid-teens ARR growth and OpEx reductions through AI automation, compared to a prior focus on growth momentum and backlog.
  • Strategic focus moved further toward AI-native product development and multiproduct deals, with new wins in pizza and entertainment verticals.
  • Management's tone remained confident, while analysts continued to probe for concrete evidence of AI's impact and profitability improvements.
  • Key metrics showed steady revenue growth, higher ARR, and ongoing margin expansion, with additional detail on cost pressures and mitigation strategies this quarter.
  • Analysts remained focused on ARR growth, margin trajectory, and the impact of AI investment.

Risks and Concerns

  • Singh highlighted ongoing cost pressures: "We saw significant cost pressures on key components, including solid-state drives, memory and processors... tightening availability and creating elevated pricing across the broader compute supply chain."
  • Management is pursuing mitigation through "supplier diversification, product flexibility and the pricing discipline to ensure we can continue supporting customers."
  • Analysts raised concerns about supply chain impacts on hardware margins and the sustainability of growth amid broader market challenges.

Final Takeaway

PAR Technology closed 2025 with record bookings, robust ARR growth, and its third consecutive quarter of non-GAAP profitability, fueled by strong momentum in AI-driven product innovation and multiproduct deals. Management anticipates continued mid-teens ARR growth, a step change in operational efficiency through $15 million in annualized OpEx savings, and sustained investment in AI platform development in 2026. The company remains confident in its strategic positioning, emphasizing its expanding AI capabilities, deepening customer relationships, and readiness to capitalize on new opportunities across its hospitality and retail platforms.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript
